Evaluation_Questions: Your level of engagement with this course compared to others you have taken was
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
How would you rate the workload of this course in comparison to other F&ES courses you have taken?
Given the course objectives, the level of intellectual challenge of the material covered was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
Comments_Questions: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
How well did the knowledge, skills, and insights gained in this class align with your expectations
What are the strengths and weaknesses of the course and how could it be improved?
What advice would you give to a student considering taking this class
Comments_List: Micro-economics
Developed very little knowledge and skills in this course.
I learned to think about economic concepts related to the environment and how to incorporate economic tradeoffs into decision-making in an environmental management setting.
I learned basic concepts of environmental economics.
Basic economic concepts and some background as to how they apply to environmental management.
I learned how economics tends to evaluate and view environmental issues.

I think Professor Mendhelson did a solid job teaching econ this semester. He was a little controversial for some students, but I think he did a good job challenging us to think differently and approach environmental topics through a different lens.

The part that needed some more work was how the course and the discussion session interflowed. We had an amazing TA ( Sam), but it felt like we did all the math in that sub section and didn't really tie it in during lecture. There were also 2 - 3 lectures in the middle of the course that disrupted flow and took away from more of the interesting topics during the second half.

I feel like I walked away with new skills and concepts, but it felt a little more disjointed than it had to in some of the other economics courses that I had taken.

As taught, it was a good exposition, introduction and overview of the principles and concepts surrounding the application of economic theory to environmental resources. This can be very useful for people from unrelated backgrounds like myself, but could be very boring or useless for people who have taken economy courses before (see below).

Overview of how economists view the environmental problems of the current day, and how economic interpretations of the environment can and do affect policy decisions, business growth, and aspects of our daily lives.

After taking this course, I have a much better understanding of resource economics and economic models as they apply to environmental subject areas such as pollution control, land use, fishing, forestry, and more. The primary insights gained consisted of looking at market mechanisms' potential to address environmental issues and assessing the proper means to value the environment and natural resources.
Foundational economic concepts and how they relate to environmental management.
How economics approach and think about major environmental topics/issues ie. localized pollution, climate change, forestry, fisheries, water allocation, non-renewable resources, etc.

I got the fundamental concept of economics and how environmental economics differs from market goods. I could grab the sense of equatjng supply and demand, marginal cost and benefit, and most importantly how to interpret changes in real world to economics equations and vice versa.
Nothing
Big-picture thinking and understanding of how we apply economic theories and models to environmental management.
I took away a cursory understanding of basic economic concepts and how to apply them to environmental considerations.
Why land is dispersed among different users the way it is, methods of valuing forests, the changing benefits of pollution abatement and other environmentally salient issues over time.
My main takeaway from this course was a basic conceptual understanding of how markets function and the economic reasons why various environmental issues cannot be trusted to the market.
Overview of environmental economics.

I developed a better understanding of economic principals, and how economist understand and study environmental and non-market goods. I developed basic economic analysis skills (demand functions), and was introduced to other tools that (integrated assessment models).
Basic economic principles used for air pollution, forestry management, fisheries, etc.
Intro to MAC curves probably most valuable.

Critical approach to the current sustainable policies 
Basic economics skills

I gained exposure and experience with foundational economic concepts and their application to environmental issues. I learned how economic models and data are used to answer questions about current and future environmental problems, from climate change to forest management, and gained insight into effective approaches for addressing these challenges within an economic framework.
Introduction to basic principles of micro-economics, and the application of those principles in environmental policy development and management

Water and land as private natural resources, managing and regulating pollution, climate change economics, managing non-renewable resources (fossil fuels, timber), common property and fisheries, global trade and international environmental treaties.

I learned the orthodox environmental economic approach to water and land allocation, pollution regulation, fisheries regulation and the management of nonrenewable resources such as fossil fuels.  I was introduced to the basics of supply and demand curves, and aggregate supply and demand curves. I also learned one environmental economist's view of the need for climate change mitigation.
I would have expected more interdisciplinary approach and link to real-work problems and realities; including developing countries' struggles to keep a clean environment.
Below expectations, did not learn very much.
The knowledge and skills I learned matched my expectations and gained a lot of knowledge that I think will benefit in a future career in environmental management.
I felt like the class was very theoretical, and sometimes hard to grasp. Many concepts went over my head.

Extremely poorly. I gain some insights on how the economy and the market work in certain scenarios, but I cannot really tell how much of it was based on real-life cases and how much it was theory that the professor wanted us to have. However, we hardly ever got examples from real life and it made all the explanations not really sink with me.

I expected a higher level of information as applicability. Much of what was offered was too basic (including both economic and environmental information), sometimes off topic, and only occasionally very insightful and new.
Fair enough.

Like I said above, I had some economic skills coming into the class. So it wasn't too bad. But I do feel like for those who had this as their first economics course, it wasn't as good as it was otherwise could have been for learning and developing those skills.

The only expectation I had with this course, if any, was to be able to hone-in on practical skills which could be applied in natural resource management, couple with acquiring insights into economic evaluations or approaches to the discipline. In all, the course was good in accomplishing this from a general, conceptual framework, but completely missed the mark on practicality.
Very good alignment! Wish we hadn't run short on time at the end, because we had to cut out some interesting content.

Previously, I had not taken an economics course and came into the course expecting to gain a deeper understanding of how economics and markets in particular influence environmental policy at the national level. I definitely walked away from this course with a deeper understanding of economic principles and how they can be applied to the environment and natural resources to produce optimum policy solutions.
It aligned well with my expectations, however, sometimes it was more basic than I would have liked.
Although I got a general sense of the economic perspective on environmental topics, the connections between the theory and the math were sorely lacking in lectures.
I didn't feel that I learned much that I hadn't already learned in Microecon undergrad--perhaps a few environmental applications, but not a whole lot.

Honestly it felt like undergrad class. I was hoping for Mendelsohn to rather create the situation where we should be immersed to reading lots of his research, or perhaps others case by case basis. But instead he opted to settle for us 'grasping' the concept by weekly problem set.

I know that we could just read his research without he had conditioned the class to. However, as people respond to incentive, it would have been better if he added reading and discussion on canvas as well.
There was zero alignment with my expectations.

Mostly aligned with my expectations. My only complaint is that it was often too theory based, I would have liked to have done more hands-on work that involved real world situations or had examples of practical applications of some of the models and theories we discussed.

This class failed to meet even my lowest expectations. I do not feel like I learned any concrete skills or concepts. The professor routinely lectured on unrelated topics and did not actually teach any of the the key concepts, instead relying on students to 'teach themselves' via problem sets. I'm not sure why we even had classroom time.
I thought the class would be more practical and include less of a "Econ 101" framework, which seemed to take a lot of time away from the class.

My knowledge and skills gained from this class did not align with my expectations. I do not feel as though I could apply these concepts to a future professional setting where there are any economic considerations.

The material aligned fairly well with my expectations. I did expect the course to go into more depth on use of economic methods, but I understand that the focus was a high level survey of different topics in environmental economics.
This course provided a good overview of the concepts, however, I would have liked to learn more economic principles that are the basis of the concepts.
Yes, but I would have liked more intro the micro theory.
Great
Well -- I appreciated the firm grounding in core microeconomic concepts, as well as the survey-style application of economics to a wide range of environmental issues.
The course's curriculum is extremely promising and attractive, but I think the course itself fell short in the delivery of the curriculum.
Met expectations. The process for acquiring the knowledge was difficult at times, but I felt I gained the knowledge, skills, and insight I expected from the class.

I had hoped to cover more material. The professor tended to go on long tangents, and sometimes we'd go an entire class period and never really talk about econ, it seemed.

I did appreciate that he focused on concepts, not formulas.
I was expecting something very different from the course.

This course aligned with my expectation that I would be taught the basics of environmental economics.  However, it did not align with my expectation that this course would challenge the current ways of thinking about economics and the environment (which are, in my view, obviously not working).  The course was very market-focussed.  For instance, we were taught that water markets are always the best way to allocate water and that "poor people will always find enough money to buy water to survive". I also expected that the course would be backed up by research.  However, it seemed to me that gross generalisations were often given, without reference to papers or books. One example is that "99.9% of common property regimes fail", seeming to ignore all of the work that has been done looking at the ability of institutions to manage common property successfully. I also did not expect the professor to only support modest mitigation of greenhouse gases before the end of the century on the basis that climate change will overall be beneficial globally up until the end of the century.  I did not expect to be told that the long term target should be 3 - 5 degrees C above pre-industrial levels, as compared to the 2 degree Paris goal.
either center it in micro economics or talk about the whole spectrum of things that are needed to achieve sustainable development (poverty reduction, inequality, etc).

Should be much improved next year, more of a thread between the courses. More working through the math and problem sets with instructor during class time. Would love to learn more policy implications as well.

I think the course can be improved by providing some kind of reference for the concepts learned in the lecture such as slides or a text book. Sometimes I found it difficult to understand a concept if I didn't grasp it during the lecture therefore it would have been great to have something to go back to in this case.
The course was difficult to succeed in. The skill sets for the problem sets were not taught in class, making them hard to complete. I constantly felt lost and confused.

The class is basically divided in three: There is one class taught in the classroom, there is another class related to the homework, and there is another class with the readings. The connection between them is poor, if not inexistent. The TA's had to give their own class for us to understand the--terribly written--homeworks. Such homeworks would require us to do things that were never explained in class, and were filled with mistakes that the TAs would need to email us or tell us in the sections in order to be able to do them. In addition, the things that we were requested to do were written in the most obscure manner ever imagined, and made us waste valuable time deciphering what the professor wanted us to do, and this didn't add any value to the task we needed to do.
The class was very frustrating. The professor would hardly ever answer to any question made by students, making our involvement futile as we were basically just listening with no possibility of real feedback. Furthermore, the classes were extremely repetitive. We would spend 40 minutes listening the same thing when it could have been summarized in one sentence. All this extra time wasted could have been used to explain the logic behind the homeworks.

I truly do appreciate Professor Mendelsohn's perspective and sometimes uncomfortable perspective on solving natural resource problems. It is important to challenge my own views even if, in the end, I still disagree. 

That being said, I think one of the weaknesses would be the frequent errors in the problem sets. It was difficult to learn the concepts when there were errors or the TAs were unsure why the solution was the way it was. 

I would also suggest that in the future the TAs be allowed to go through the PSETs step by step in sections or have an alternative PSET to go through with us. Since we don't learn these equations or how to solve them in lecture, we need to learn it somewhere. 

But again, I have truly appreciated this class and the perspectives presented in lecture! Thank you!

Strengths:
-Straight forward expectations
- Wide range of topics

Weaknesses:
- Information on how to do problem sets was almost entirely taught by the TAs
- Too basic. We are graduate students, not everything needs to be a straight line since that's not realistic
- Lecture had no discussion, just being talked at. If section is supposed to be time for discussion, teach to the problem set in class even just a little bit.
The mathematical foundation for the problem set could be focused more in class.

I think just a little more focus for some of the middle lectures could help Professor Mendelsohn really improve the course. There was just one on climate science that stood out as being more of a basics course than just an economics view. Some of the lectures could have been condensed to get to fisheries, forestry, non-renewables, and other important aspects of natural resource economics.

The main strength of the course was the entertaining and compelling in-class lectures provided by the professor. For the most part, they were able to communicate concepts and their visualization through graphs rather effectively. The main weakness was precisely in failing to break down to the students (and from what was obvious, to the TFs themselves) just how these visualization of data came about. There were the lectures in the one hand, the readings on the other (if at all) and the required problem sets in the other, and these made up the worst part of the course, as they usually had no link or stated relationship with the lectures (beside their topics) and a great amount of time had to be invested in merely understanding WHAT they were about and how to go about with them. At times this felt like two separate courses and while the TFs seemingly put a lot of effort into making this work, they often felt as misled and improvising as the rest of us.

I really liked the lecture style and the blackboard diagrams. Great attitude from the professor all the time, he really seemed to enjoy teaching the course which really makes it easy for students to be engaged with the material. Great examples from real life. Professor sometimes should have shut down some of the questions quicker to keep us on track. Perhaps a little bit less USA-centered, some of the topics really only made sense for North American environments or businesses. Perhaps the first couple weeks could have started with something more immediately understandable, it was a bit hard to figure out for the first couple weeks and I know a couple people who shopped and dropped it because they didnt realize how much cooler the material was going to get!! Overall though I loved the course and the way the lectures were conducted. So glad I stuck with it!

The strengths of the course include coverage of a wide variety of topics such as fishing, forestry, travel costs, land use, pollution control and more; very helpful and accessible teaching fellows; Prof. Mendelsohn's experience and passion for the subject area; and problem sets that allow students to understand course concepts mathematically and practically. The weaknesses of the course include difficulty following course concepts without complementary digital resources (lecture materials only drawn on chalkboard) and the variety of topics covered not allowing for a deep dive on all topics.

Strengths: Teaching of economic content

Weaknesses: Teaching of environmental concepts
More systematic ways of delivery might be good to render course more interesting.

I think the professor's lectures could have been way more focused and actually on economics; as it turned out, slides with actual numbers and clearer diagrams would have been better--and would have kept him better on track.

Strentgh: broad cases, firm grasp on economic fundamentals, challenge our perspective
Weakness: not a course for you those who want a 'reflective' course

Most of the classes were off topic, we talked about many things that weren't even related with economics. The problem sets were never seen in class, so the homework had nothing to do with what we learned in class. I think that in average, three classes could have been easily taught in one class. We wasted a lot of time going over and over the same topics without even asking about it. Our questions were never answered, he kept on delaying the answer for some reason, but we never understood why.

More focus on economics, less on general climate change discussion. Also, I would have really benefited from the instructor reviewing some of the math we needed to complete models. Having the TAs be the only ones teaching the math was not productive and at times even confusing.

This course needs direction and rigor. What are the learning objectives? What concepts will be taught? The classroom lectures should add to the course content, not serve as a platform for the professor to pontificate on tangental topics.
Give more attention to the aspects of class that were in the syllabus but weren't touched on very much (only a mention or two in lecture).

The course felt very disjointed. The math-based problem sets were totally different material than the lectures, but they did not really help with understanding the material (they just felt kind of extra). The main point of the class seemed to be driving home the concepts, not the math, which I think is a good thing, but the homework assignments should still support the rest of the course material rather than just feeling like busywork.
The lecture was often repetitive or tangential. Aside from marginal benefit and marginal demand, I do not feel like we developed proficiency in any other economic theory.

Strengths: some of the lectures were very good, and I have a good understanding of many topics covered in the class. The readings were interesting and informative. The TAs and their discussion groups were excellent. Weaknesses: some lectures were repetitive. The homework was simple and did not require or encourage strong engagement with the material. There was little connection between the lectures and the readings.
The course covered a lot of material and provided good discussion points. At the same time, sometimes lectures seemed to be too in depth and not as relevant to the overarching concepts.
Some lectures didn't seem to fit with the class at all. Almost no feedback.

Professor has a deep knowledge in his field and was able to share it very effectively. 

Opportunities: study materials (homeworks and readings) could be better synchronized with the lecture

This course effectively introduces students to an economic worldview, which I believe is important to understand in order to make an effective case for environmental solutions to decision-makers who are primarily concerned with economic issues. It also covers a broad range of material, and supplementary readings are drawn from leaders in the environmental economics field. 

A weakness of the course were the poorly-structured discussion sections, which could have been better planned and implemented in order to further students' learning. They were essentially problem set review sessions, which seems like something better reserved for office hours. I think they should have included more discussion of the readings assigned for homework, and/or the application of concepts learned in class to current environmental issues and events.

Great curriculum, but delivery could be improved. May recommend establishing a foundation textbook that provides an introduction to environmental economics (covering both basic economic principles which students may not have been introduced to, as well as how these principles are applied in an environmental management context). 

Students also struggled with some of the mathematics in the course, which were presented mainly in the problem sets. There was significant disconnect between the mathematics application required in the problem sets, and what was taught during lectures (which focused very specifically on the theoretical elements).

Many of the lectures felt very slow, and caused us to get behind in the syllabus. I really enjoyed a handful of the lectures, especially about managing non-renewable resources or common property. 

I was frustrated at times by the lack of alignment between homework problem sets and class content. The homework assignments required math that we never went over during class sessions, and often had to be entirely learned during TA sessions. I would have preferred to get a grasp/introduction to the math in class, and then use the homework assignments as an opportunity to dive deeper and become more comfortable with it.

Strengths: Definitely geared towards individuals who want to understand some economics, but are not looking to become an economist. Even something not particularly strong in math could take the course and understand all the material.

Weaknesses: The class material didn't prepare you for the problem sets. If the TAs hadn't been so good, I'm confident many of us would have gotten failing grades on the problem sets. We didn't cover as much material as we could have because the professor would get sidetracked. Often he would say he would come back to a question, and then forget.

The strength of this course is that it covers a broad range of environmental economic issues. The primary weakness is that the lecturer does not challenge the current ways of thinking about the environment using economics. The lectures also did not connect to the course readings - I would recommend linking the readings and the lectures together.  For instance, I would have found it very helpful to have references to papers that supported and disputed the sweeping claims made by the lecturer. I also found the questions in the problem sets and exams to be quite vague - I would recommend that the TAs be allowed to do a test run of the assessments to make sure that the instructions are clear.  The problems sets were also not closely linked to the lectures - it was usually up to the TAs to actually teach us the skills necessary to complete the problem sets. I would also recommend that the lecturer recommend an environmental economics textbook for students to refer to (not just a general economics textbook). Another recommendation is that the problem sets include questions that required written explanations of the concepts we were being taught. As it was, most of the marks in the two exams came from written explanations, even though we had not previously had an opportunity to test our ability to put what we were being taught into words (rather than equations or diagrams).
Class needs to be much better organize. Sam Maher as TA was extremely helpful to all students in her section and helped a lot with learning the material.
I would suggest that they attend lectures and that they attend the TA review sessions because they were also helpful in understanding the concepts.
Do not take it.

I would first suggest not to take this course, as I regret I took it. Secondly, I would say that the course is interesting if you want to learn about certain theoretical economic approaches, but that don't really translate to reality or have little examples in the world.
If you have had any basic economics, skip this class, it is not worth it.
Take the course, as it is foundational, but prepare for a bit of disjointedness. Know that Professor M sometimes may seem controversial but he is trying to make you think differently.
Wait until another instructor offers it before taking it as a foundational requirement of the MEM. Skip altogether if this is not the case.

Great overview of an important field; covering topics that are important to people working in policy and business. Something for everyone-- even for activists or anti-capitalists! Economic principles are a big part of the basic fabric of our society/ world and we all should understand the field.

If you are not an economics major/minor and have not taken a course in economics as it applies to environmental challenges I highly recommend taking this course. The content will be beneficial to careers in environmental policy and resource management. I would recommend that students interested in taking this course be prepared to dive into the material, attend TF office hours and additional student sections outside of class, and ask many questions in class until the material is clearly understood.
If you have solid understanding of economic concepts you may not want to take this class.
Shop the course and pay attention to who is teaching and whether you like their teaching style. It could make or break this course for you.
If it's necessary for your degree, or being taught markedly differently, sure, but if it's the same course as fall 2017 and you have any econ experience, take something higher level.
Take it if you're new at econ and want to know more. Don't take it if you are looking for challenge
I dont recommend the class, unless you have no knowledge at all about environmental economics, but otherwise take other economic courses with another professor.
Don't, spend 30 minutes on Khan academy and you will learn more.
Only take if you haven't had any previous exposure to economics.
Go into the class expecting to take away broad concepts about environmental economics.
Read the course papers even if they are not required for any homework or discussions.
If they would like to learn about the economics of water, land, and pollution it will provide you with a lot of valuable insight.
It's what we got in terms of foundational econ.
Strongly recommended.

I would recommend this class, and I would strongly advise taking it with a open mind. While some of the economic concepts were not in line with my worldview, I was glad to be exposed to the ideas of the class because I recognize that much of our governing structures operate according to the economic logic presented by the professor. I believe it's important to understand that logic in order to effectively advocate for better governmental or market-driven solutions to environmental problems. In that sense, this class is really valuable for providing students with a grasp of basic economic concepts, and how they can be used to address environmental issues.
A promising foundation course.
Good foundational course. I think the content is quite useful, and is probably worth bearing through some of the challenges in how it was taught.

See who the TAs are if it's taught by the same professor and strongly weigh that in your decision. It's a low work load, which is nice, but also you aren't going to be bursting with new information after each class.

I would check who is teaching the class before taking it.  If it was possible to take Economics of the Environment with a lecturer other than Prof Mendelsohn, I would seriously consider doing that. Otherwise, I would say to take many of the sweeping statements made by the lecturer with a grain of salt, so to speak. 
I think that taking some environmental economics is worthwhile though. And this was certainly an interesting introduction to the economics discourse from someone who is heavily invested in market ideology.
